HTML Input form* Attributes Previous Next This chapter describes the different form* attributes for the HTML element. The form Attribute The input form attribute specifies the form the element belongs to. The value of this attribute must be equal to the id attribute of the
element it belongs to. Example An input field located outside of the HTML form (but still a part of the form):

Try it Yourself The formaction Attribute The input formaction attribute specifies the URL of the file that will process the input when the form is submitted. Note: This attribute overrides the action attribute of the
element. The formaction attribute works with the following input types: submit and image. Example An HTML form with two submit buttons, with different actions:



Try it Yourself The formenctype Attribute The input formenctype attribute specifies how the form-data should be encoded when submitted (only for forms with method="post"). Note: This attribute overrides the enctype attribute of the
element. The formenctype attribute works with the following input types: submit and image. Example A form with two submit buttons. The first sends the form-data with default encoding, the second sends the form-data encoded as "multipart/form-data":
